awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Secure Quantum Communication with Limited Resources
awd_abstract_narration:
Developing a communication infrastructure, secure against powerful adversaries (with potential access to advanced quantum computers and capabilities), is of vital importance to our society.  Using only classical communication, two parties cannot establish a shared secret key (needed to securely communicate with one another) unless some computational assumption is made on the power of the adversary.  However, by carefully using the power of quantum communication, one can achieve unconditional security for this task.  This project seeks to understand the capabilities of quantum communication protocols where users have only limited access to quantum functionality while an adversary has unlimited access to such resources.  These limitations on the users may be intentional (for instance, to reduce the cost of a quantum communication device), or unintentional (for instance, if a device malfunctions or breaks down during operation). The work in this project will provide new theoretical results of broad application to quantum information science and also pave the way for a future communication infrastructure that is highly secure, practical, and robust to device failure and cost limitations.  Besides the theoretical and practical benefits of this work, there are also impacts in this project in educational activities and outreach efforts.  The work on this project will enable undergraduate researchers an opportunity to not only contribute to quantum cryptographic research, but to also learn and gain insight into this important field.  The future will see a vast increase in the use of quantum technologies, making the education of students in this field all the more important.

This project will develop a deeper understanding of the theoretical foundations of secure quantum communication by discovering and analyzing novel quantum cryptographic protocols that utilize participants with limited quantum functionality.  The research efforts involve analyzing these limited-resource protocols in a variety of security models (including various forms of device independence) and devise innovative methods for users, despite having limited quantum capabilities, to counter an adversarial agent allowing for highly secure, and efficient, communication systems, even over high-noise channels.  To achieve this, the PI will also be developing new quantum information theoretic techniques needed to analyze these protocols in such highly restricted setting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Quantum cryptography promises a future communication infrastructure secure against future adversaries equipped with quantum computing capabilities.  Unlike classical key distribution, quantum key distribution (QKD) does not require computational assumptions on the adversary to be proven secure.  However, "how quantum" does a protocol need to be to gain this advantage?  What's in the "gap" between classical and quantum communication and how secure are such protocols?  This project's goal was to study these questions ? developing new protocols and new security proof methods.  The new protocols developed require fewer quantum capabilities from users (making them also potentially more economical to implement); our new security proof methods show novel reductions to fully-quantum protocols and may see broad application for other researchers in the field.

Over the course of the project, several new QKD protocols were developed which: (1) require fewer and less precise measurement capabilities on the users; (2) require fewer (if any) state preparation abilities; and (3) can operate through the use of an untrusted quantum server.  I highlight just a few published papers:

1. A. Gagliano, W.O. Krawec, and H. Iqbal. From Classical to Semi-Quantum Secure Communication. Proc. IEEE ISIT 2019, Paris France, pages 1707-1711. (2019)
In this paper, we developed a novel QKD protocol that can smoothly transition from a purely classical key distribution protocol (where unconditional security is not possible) to a fully quantum one (where unconditional security is possible).  This was done through a "tuning" parameter.  We derived a key-rate expression for the protocol for any setting of this parameter allowing us to show when the protocol became secure.  This protocol lives in the "gap" between classical and quantum protocols mentioned earlier.

2. O. Amer and W.O. Krawec. Semi-Quantum Key Distribution with High Quantum Noise Tolerance. Physical Review A 100 (2) 022319. (2019) pre-print available online: arXiv:1812.04144
In this paper, we showed how a two-way quantum communication channel can be strategically used to boost noise tolerance of a semi-quantum protocol (one where severe device restrictions are placed on one of the users).  Our method to boost performance may be applicable to a broad class of other QKD protocols (semi-quantum or otherwise).  Our methods do not require additional complexity beyond the two-way communication channel.

3. J. Guskind and W.O. Krawec. Mediated Semi-Quantum Key Distribution with Improved Efficiency. Quantum Science and Technology. Volume 7(3) 035019. pre-print available online: arXiv:2111.01627
In this paper, we improved the performance of a "mediated" semi-quantum protocol (one which requires an untrusted quantum server, but allows the users to have minimal quantum capabilities).  Importantly, we also developed a novel method to "reduce" the protocol to an entanglement based one, allowing more advanced mathematical tools to be applied to it to prove security.  Our methods may be broadly applicable to other protocols.

4. Massa, F., Yadav, P., Moqanaki, A., Krawec, W. O., Mateus, P., Paunkovic, N., ... & Walther, P. (2022). Experimental semi-quantum key distribution with classical users. Quantum, 6, 819. (2022)
In this paper, we developed a novel semi-quantum QKD protocol where users do not need to prepare quantum states and required minimal measurement capabilities.  Furthermore, it is secure against a large class of practical attacks.  Finally, an experimental proof of concept was developed showing the feasibility of such protocols.

Overall, this project has greatly advanced our knowledge of "how quantum" protocols need to be, both by developing novel protocols with limited resource requirements and by developing the mathematical tools necessary to prove them secure.

The project funded a PhD student who was involved in the research and manuscript writing/preparation.  The project also created numerous opportunities for undergraduate student researchers to become involved.  Several undergraduate students were involved in papers published through this project.  These undergrads were co-authors on the papers and many have gone on, or or planning on going on, to graduate school for their PhD.

Educational opportunities were also created through this project.  Many of the results were used in my classes on quantum computing.  For instance the protocol developed in [4] above I use often in my very first lecture as it shows several interesting features of quantum communication and serves as a useful motivational example for learning the material.

Secure communication is vital to our society and this project shows how we can get unconditional security with even fewer quantum resources than previously thought necessary.  This work can lead to an improvement in our communication infrastructure without needing to invest in a multitude of high-cost quantum devices.
